description: From Middle English brunt, bront (“sudden onset, attack, charge, blow”), from Old Norse brundr or brundtíð (“oestrus, rut”) (from Proto-Germanic *brunstiz), or bruna (“to rush”, literally “to advance like wildfire”) (see brenna).

entries.meaning: The full adverse effects; the chief consequences or negative results of a thing or event.
examples: Unfortunately, poor areas such as those in New Orleans bore the brunt of Hurricane Katrina’s winds.

entries.meaning: The force or shock of an attack in war.
The major part of something; the bulk.
examples: If you feel tired of walking, just think of the poor donkey who has carried the brunt of our load.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A violent attack or charge in battle.
(obsolete, by extension) A sudden harmful onset or attack (of disease, unbelief, persecution, etc.).
(obsolete) A spurt, a sudden effort or straining.

verbs.description: brunt (third-person singular simple present brunts, present participle brunting, simple past and past participle brunted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To bear the brunt of; to weather or withstand.
(intransitive, obsolete) To make a violent attack or charge.
